document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. Burke, Charlie Johnson, Pit zer Johnson, William Burke, D. A. Conner, D. E. Turnes, Jesse L. Tumes, James W. Caldwell, Harry Jenkins, Leonard Carter, E. Percy Sea, Odel! Howerton, Edmund H. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Cheatham, Dr. L L. Gayle, Dr. C. F. James, Robert Hubbard, Fitz Martin, Calvin H. Robinson, George F. Abbitt, Jr., T. W. Ferguson, Lester B. Harvey, J. D. Plunkett. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox.  And death itself, to him, was but The wider opening of the door Tha had been opening, more and more, Through all his life, and nevei as stiut. . . .

document.text: W e heartily concur in the sugges tion contained in the letter of Mr. J. R. Horsley published in another column in reference to a good roads maes meeting here next court day. Our roads are indeed in a deplorable condition and some system must be devised to improve them. We are inclined to favor the old system. It is true the court of Appeals in the Proflit case which went up from Louisa county, held in effect, that to require a citizen to work on the road was the imposition of a poll tax on said citizen and as the constitution only authorized, a poll-tax of one and a half dollars, all laws enacting the labor system were unconstitutional. We have never seen the full text of this de oision, but we are constrained to the belief that there is something in the Louisu law, peculiar to itself to justify such a finding by our appellate court. We know that such was the opiuion of our A tty for the Commonwealth nearly a year ugo and that at that time he filed an opinion with Judge Chris tian bolding this view and advising the court to enforce the old sys tem. At any rate the effort to enforce thiB system should be tried now and if there is complaint let a case be made up and taken to the new court of Appeals. This court has just reversed the decision of the old court in the ceV ebrated Mary Miller case. This de cision was rendered by the old court iu January 1892 and since that tim has cost the people of this State more than a quarter of a million of dollars. By the Mary Miller decis ion the old court took from Justices of the Peace, almost all of their criminal jurisdiction and forced the county courts to try even the most trivial ctises. By their reversal of this decision the new Democcratic court restored to the J. Ps. their jurisdiction, which will save to the taxpayers large sums of money annu ally. We believe if the road question was taken to the new court, the Proffit case would meet with the same fate as the Mary Milier case

document.text: Tlie County Com m ittee M eets. A meeting of the Democratic Ex ecutive Committee of the county was held at the court-house yesterday morning, nearly every member of the committee being present. They were Mr. W. J. Trent, Chairman, Mr. Joseph Button, Secretary, and Messrs. J. R. Horsley, J. T. Moses, W. A. Moses, Cary Carson, T. E. LeGrand, R. W. Worley, and S. P. Taylor. The committee was called together to determine the time,place and man ner of electing delegates to the con gressional convention, to be held at Buchanan, August 16th. After a full and free discussion of the mat ter, it was decided unanimously to follow the method of electing dele gates which has been in vogue for mauy years in this county, that is by mass meeting at the court-house. The reason for this is obvious. It would he impossible to elect delegates by precinct meetings, as there are more precincts than delegates to be elected, and some precincts casting more votes than others, there could not be a just apportionment. Be sides, there is always a large crowd in attendance npon county court, and we will he more apt to get a fair expression of the sentiment of the people, as a great mauy attend court who would not turn out to a precinct meeting. The committee fixed next Thursday, the first day of the June term of court, as the day for the mass meeting

document.text: THIRD d a y  s SESSION. The Ministers Relief Fund was considered, seyeral laymen speaking, and then various matters were con sidered. The thanks of the body, by a ris ing vote, were extended to Hon. J. R. Horsley for an excellent map of the Association which hung on the wall during the Association pre pared by him. Rev. C. A. Woodson was elected a delegate to the Southern Baptist Convention, and the churches were urged to pay his travelling expenses. The Association decided to hold its next session in Burkeville, when Rev. S. H. Thompson will preach the introductory sermon. Just before adjournment, a hearty vote of thanks was extended by a rising vote to the Hollywood church aud commun-ty for their large and ample aud handsome hos pitality. The closing hourB of the Associa tion were given to an End-of-the- Century celebration, when the fol lowing programme was carried out Prayer, Rev. P. T. Warren Address, Baptists of the Past Century, Dr. Robert Frazer Address, Baptists of the Present, Rev. W. J. Ship- man  Address, Missions of the Nineteenth Century, Dr. George Braxton Taylor Address, Mission ary Outlook, Rev. J. H. Couch Address, Lessons from Past Expe riences, Rev. S. H. Thompson Prayer, Rev, C. A. Woodson. By motion, the pastors of the As sociation were requested during the coming year to hold in each charch at least four services in which the work of the closing century and the outlook for the coming century be considered. The following preachers and pas tors in the Association were present at the sessions of the body W. J. Shipman, J. B. Williams, S. H. Thompson, R. W. Cridlin, J. Reees. J. M. Periy, C. A. Wocdson, P. T. Warren, J. H. Couch, J. W. Snyder. 0 . S. Hubble, Geo. B. Taylor. Rev. J. R. Doan and Rev. H. T. Williams were absent on account of sickness. The session of the body is consid ered one of the best in its history.

document.text: The marriage of Rev. E. M. Craig, cf this place, and Miss L. Lynwood, Glenn, of Campbell, was celebrated in the Episcopal Church at Rust- burg, at half past ten yesterday morning, Rev. J. M. Wells, of Bu ena Vista officiating. The church was beautifully dec orated with ferns and flo .ers, and the chancel was a dream of exquisite colors artistically blended. White and green and gold were so delicately interwoven that the eye wandered with delight from object to object. The ensemble was unu sually tasteful and uniquely pic turesque. At the time appointed the church was packed with a large and distin guished looking audience, and Dr. Carrington, the master of ceremon ies,found his hands full in attending to the eager crowd. Promptly at half past ten the beautiful and inspiriting strains of Mendelsohns wedding march, skil fully rendered by our talented musi cian, Miss Anna Jones, announced to the expectant assemblage the im mediate approach of the bridal party. Slowly up the centre aisle came the ushers, Messrs. J. R. Horsley, H. W. McLaughlin, of Hampden Sidney,W. J. Trent,and J. M. Miles. On reaching the chancel they separ ated and took positions facing each other. Following them came the maid of honor, Miss Louise Carring ton, the charming and accomplished daughter of Dr. Carrington. She stood on the left. After her came the bride on the arm of her brother irr-law, M r. -------- Yewell. As she approached the altar she was met by the groom, who with his best man, Mr. E. Govan Hill of Manchester, had been waiting in the vestry room. They then placed themselves before the altar, Mr. Hill being on the right. Amid soft notes from the organ theminister impressively pronounced the marriage service of the Presby terian church, and with a heartfelt benediction dismissed the congrega tion. The bridal party filed out in opposite order. Mr. and Mrs. Craig were driven directly to the station where they i took the train for Pamplin City via Lynchburg.

document.text: The Concord Meeting. The Richmond Dispatch publish es the following extract from a let ter from its Apponiatiox correspond ent, of dale September 7th 1 saw iu your correspondence from Pamplius yesterday a statement that C. H. Chiiti n, of this county, is the Tyler Democratic candidate tor the legislature to represent this county and Campbell i had for merly seen a stateuieut in your paper in a letter from Concord to the ef fect that Mr. Chilton was uomiua- t d at a muss-meetiug held at Con- coid, at which 362 voters were pres ent in person or by proxy. 1 have intended for some time to correct the statement contained iu the Concord letter, but not having been present at that meeting, 1 had to wait until J could get my facts accurately, which I give you as fol lows  The meeting was called by people who have for years antagonized the Democratic party. All persons, ir respective of political parties, who favored Governor Tylers election to the United Stater Senate were invi ted to participate in it. It was not a meeting iu the form of a conven tion or one iu u inch the people ton Id be represented by delegates, bufc-was called as a muss meeting. There .ere presett by actual count twenty-nine voters,, twenty-three of whom were from Appomattox and six from Campbell. Turn not post ed as toChe politics of all the Camp bell participants, but I am very fa miliar with the politics of those who attended the meeting from Appo mattox. Only one of themviz., Mr. L. A- Williams, a brother-in-law of Mr. C. H. Chiltonshas been considered a Democrat for the past four years. Some of the most prom inent figures in it were W. C. Frank lin, county chairman of the Repub lican party of Appomattox, who has time and again been the Republican candidate for various offices H. E. Gilliam, a leading Republican F. B. .ones, T. H. A. Cheatham, C. B. Blox ton, and Hut Ferguson colored other prominent Republicans. In justice to Hut, it should be stated that when the resolution was passed by themeeting declaring that no money should be used in the interest of tne nominee, he left in disgust. The meeting in no sense repre sents any DemocVatic sentiment iu Appomattox county. There hasj bean no split in the Democratic par ty here, and 1 do not believe there has been or will be any in Campbell, but I know the Democrats of our county are solid for the regular nom ine, Mr. J. R. Horsley. We think it an injustice not only to our nominee but to our people to characterize a meeting gotten up and dominated by leading Republi- eani as a Democratic meeting, when the other man they nominated if, by any mishap, he should be elected, would not be admitted into a Dem ocratic CUUCU8, Mr. Chilton himself has not voted the Democratic ticket for at least four years, and probably longer. M r. J. R. Horsley was nominated by a Democratic mass-meeting which was the largest meetiug of the kind held in this county in the recollect ion of its oldest inhabitants. It. was fully representative of the wishes of the party. It was held after due uotice and after an active cau vass of the county by Mr, Horsleys fiiends and the friends of I is opponent,

document.text: The Campbell Convention. The convention to nominate a member of the House of Delegates from Campbell and the floater from Appomattox met at Rustbnrg Mon day aud nominated Captaiu J. C. Featberstone aud ratified the nomi nation of Mr. W. H. Ligon, of this county. Dr. Terrill nominated Capt. Featherstone and his nomiua tion was made unanimous. The Lynchburg Press says Major Adam Clement moved that the convention ratify the selection by Appomattox of the name of W. H. Ligon as floater, which was adopted. Mr. Ligon being present was introduced to the convention and responded in a well timed speech, and made a fine impression upon the people. Major Daniel presided over the convention and made one of his fine speeches. The convention endorsee him for the Senate. A resolution referring the matter of the county judgship to the people to be voted upon was laid on the table. The convention was harmonious and well attended und Campbell will give her old time major ities for tbe Democratic nominees this tall. The following delegates attended from this county J . H. Robertson,  A. H. Howerton, J. R. Horsley and R. W. Bristow.

After the meal had been served, Ivan Scruggs gave very interestingly the status of the F. F. V. organization, outlined briefly the history followed by Mr. W alter S. Newman, State Supervisor, who stressed the responsibiity of both father and son, and spoke of the impressive record agricultural students were making in the State colleges as shown by a recent study. Following this several of the boys gave very interesting re ports on chapter activities and supervised practice work, hey were Frank Cawthorn, lorace Shirey and Alfred lawson. Others who made talks were Senator S. L. Ferguson, Ion. J. R. Horsley, A. R. Har wood, R. L. Burke, J. A. Burke and Frank Cawthorn, Sr. i. W. Wilkins, instructor of the class, closed the meeting with a few words, in which he urged the fathers to cooperate in the local program of work. document.text: T ra n s p o rta tio n a n d C o m m u n ica tio n Ease and speed of transportation and communication are tremendous factors in our modern life. From practically no means of transportation or communication, other than the stage coach, and mail, we have developed until today Appomattox County is one of the most accessible places in the State. We have the main double track line of the N.  W. Railway pass ing east and west nearly through the center of the County, with primary hard surfaced highways traversing the County from east to west and north to south, and are served by through pas senger and freight bus lines, and in addition, have a local tele phone system, with the American Telephone  Telegraph Co., and Western Union Telegraph lines running through the Coun ty, with offices maintained therein. Our highway system being largely due to the efforts of the late Samuel L. Ferguson and J. R. Horsley, with the cooperation of our Board of Supervisors.

document.text: STONEWALL Rev. Senterfit, of Florida, is assisting Rev. A. I Candle in a revival at Hebron Church this week. Services will continue thru Sunday evening. Col. Joseph Button, and wife, of Richmond, visited their coun try home at Walkers Ford last week and were at Stonewall Tuesday to cast their ballots. Mrs. Jennie Bondurant, of Six Mile Bridge and her cousin, Mrs. Ruby Callaham, of Atlanta, Ga., visited the formers sister, Mrs. T. A. Drinkard and Mrs. W. H. Erinkard. Supervisor S. E. Anderson, J. P. Alvis, Hon. J. R. Horsley, Street Thornhill and C. E. Car- son attended the Farmers Short Course at V. P-1. last week. Cards were received last week from Mr. and Mrs. B. D. Strat ton announcing the birth of a son. Lyle Harding, of Norfolk, spent some days with his par ents, Mr. and Mrs. Charlie Hard ing last week. Mr. and Mrs. Brent Stratton and little daughter, Margaret Bruce, of Greensboro, N. C., are visiting the formers parents, Mr. and Mrs. E. M. Stratton. Mrs. Brent Strattons father, Mr. Stevens, visited in this home last week. Misses Elizabeth Giles and Frances Drinkard, of Lynch burg. are spending this week with Mr. and Mrs. F. E. Jen- nings. document.text: Stonewall Democrats Organize. An enthusiastic crowd of Demo crats met at Shearers store, Stone wall precinct, yesterday evening and organized a Stonewall, Bryan. Sewall and Flood, Free Silver Club with 39 members and elected the following officers J. S. Thornhill, President H. S. Anderson, first Vice-President S. C. Stratton, J. D. Alvis, W. S. Tay lor, H. C. Babcock, H. D. LeGrand, vice Presidents J. R. Horsley, Sec retary and C. M. Stratton, Treas urer. After perfecting the organization, the club adjourned to meet Saturday Sept. 26th, at 7 p. m. The following committees were appointed On arrangement S. E. Anderson, W. O. Shearer and Ced. E. Drinkard. To Secure Speakers S. C. Strat ton, T. H. Lewis and J. R. Horsley. There is a good deal of enthus iasm and we hope to double our members at the next meeting, as many were prevented from being present that would have joined.

document.text: Sixty-four delegates, with a fourth of a vote each, were elect ed to attend the state democratic convention in Roanoke on June 21, Governor Byrds program, including the proposed amend ments to the constitution, was endorsed and achievements of Senator S. L. Ferguson and Dele gate Albert Terrell in the Gener al Assembly were commended at a mass meeting of democratic voters last Friday. Don Moses, chairman of the county democratic committee called the meeting to order anc Senator Ferguson was elected chairman of the meeting while C. W. Spnith was chosen as its secretary. A resolution proposed by Mr. Smith and unanimously adopted provided that 64 delegates with a fourth vote vote each be sent to Roanoke that the chairman of the meeting appoint a com mittee of three, one from each magisterial district, to nominate these delegates that the dele gates from the county vote as a unit at the convention easting their ballots as a majority of them might determine and that those present at the convention cast the entire vote of the dele gation. Joel Flood introduced a reso lution expressing appreciation of the able representation given the county in the house of delegates by Colonel Terrell and commend ing him particularly for his ad vocacy of a change in the  nieth- od of gasolene tax distribution which would be more fair to the poorer counties in the state than the method now in use. J. R. Horsley introduced a resolution in which he praised Senator Ferguson for his activi ties representing the county in the state senate and both of these resolutions were unanimously adopted. , Senator Ferguson introduced following resolutions Whereas, the voters of Ap pomattox county are happy to have with us to-day, Governor Byrd, who will explain to the voters of. our county, the consti tutional amendments, to be voted on at the special election, to be held on June 19. Now, Therefore, Be It Re solved That we commend the fair and forceful campaign our governor is making, for which too much praise and commenda tion cannot be given. His high character and ability has reflected itself in his splendid administra tion. In a word, he has proven himself to be a great Virginian, and a matchless leader. Be it further resolved That we are in thorough accord with the far-sighted, broad-minded progessive and economic policies which he has advocated, and which have been written into the law of our state, which now stands in the front rank of the Union. Delegates to the Roanoke con vention were chosen from the various precincts as follows and the report of the nominating committee was adopted without a dissenting vote Courthouse S. L. Ferguson, R.L. Burke, H. W. McKinney J. A. Bingham, Charles F. Han- enkrat, W. F. Woolf oik, H. L. Spencer, B. W. Babcock, L. F. Ferguson, S. L. Ferguson, Jr., C. T. Moses, N. A. Wagers, W L. Brown, E LeRoy Smith, W L. Ould, J. E. Sears, N. B Featherston, Don Moses, H. G Johnson, C. T. Evans, D. A Connor, H. 8. Coleman, W W Woodson. R. F. J amer son.

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.
